(Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: rand()] [Deterministic RNG] Can the test_rng() produce deterministic sequences that could be exploited if these benchmark utilities were accidentally imported into production code, allowing attackers to predict cryptographic values? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: rand()] [RNG State] Is test_rng() thread-safe when used across multiple benchmark iterations, or could concurrent benchmark execution lead to RNG state corruption causing non-random values in cryptographic operations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: rand()] [Type Confusion] Could the generic UniformRand trait bound allow instantiation with non-cryptographic types that have predictable distributions, leading to invalid benchmark results masking real vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_add()] [Integer Overflow] When benchmarking addition with field elements or large integers, could overflow conditions be silently ignored during benchmarking, hiding potential production overflow vulnerabilities in cryptographic computations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_add()] [Type Safety] Can the generic Add trait be exploited with types that have non-associative or non-commutative addition, causing benchmarks to misrepresent actual cryptographic operation security properties? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_add()] [Timing Side-Channel] Does the addition benchmark account for constant-time operations, or could variable-time additions leak information about operand values through timing analysis of benchmark results? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_add()] [Memory Safety] Could the addition operation on generic types trigger unsafe memory access patterns that are not caught during benchmarking but could cause memory corruption in production? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_clone()] [Deep Copy] When cloning cryptographic structures, could shallow copying semantics leak sensitive key material across security boundaries if benchmark patterns are replicated in production code? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_clone()] [Memory Leak] Could the clone operation on large cryptographic objects cause memory exhaustion during benchmarking, hiding potential DoS vectors in production validator nodes? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_clone()] [Zeroization] Does cloning cryptographic material properly zeroize the source after clone, or could benchmarks reveal that sensitive data persists in memory after supposed destruction? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-crypto/benches/bench_utils.rs] [Function: bench_function_clone()] [Reference Counting] For types using Arc/Rc internally, could clone operations during benchmarking create unexpected reference count patterns leading to use-after-free in production? (Low)
